mercury.first:
^800The smallest planet in our solar system and^100
nearest to the Sun, Mercury is only slightly ^100
larger than Earth's Moon.
mercury.introduction:
^800surface temperatures :800°F(430°C) ~ -290°F(-180°C)^100
the fastest planet, zipping around the Sun every ^100
88 Earth days.
mercury.namesake: ^800named for the swiftest of the ancient Roman gods.
mercury.potential:
^1000Mercury's environment is not conducive to life ^100
as we know it. The temperatures and solar radiation that^100
characterize this planet are most likely too extreme for^100
organisms to adapt to.
mercury.structure:
^800Mercury is the second densest planet, after Earth.^100
It has a large metallic core with a radius of about 1,289 miles^100
(2,074 kilometers), about 85% of the planet's radius. There is^100
evidence that it is partly molten or liquid. Mercury's outer shell,^100
comparable to Earth's outer shell(called the mantle and crust),^100
is only about 400 kilometers (250 miles) thick.

venus.first:
^800the second planet from the Sun, and the sixth^100
largest planet. It’s the hottest planet^100
in our solar system.
venus.introduction:
^800the second planet from the Sun, and Earth's^100
closest planetary neighbor. Venus is the third brightest object^100
in the sky after the Sun and Moon. Venus spins slowly in^100
the opposite direction from most planets.
venus.namesake:
^800named for the ancient Roman goddess of love and beauty,^100
who was known as Aphrodite to the ancient Greeks. Most features^100
on Venus are named for women. It’s the only planet^100
named after a female god.
venus.potential:
^1000Thirty miles up (about 50 kilometers) from the^100
surface of Venus temperatures range from 86 to 158 Fahrenheit^100
(30 to 70 Celsius). This temperature range could accommodate Earthly life,^100
such as “extremophile” microbes. And atmospheric pressure at that^100
height is similar to what we find on Earth’s surface.^100

At the tops of Venus’ clouds,^100
whipped around the planet by winds measured as high as 224 mph (360 kph),^100
we find another transformation. Persistent, dark streaks appear. Scientists^100
are so far unable to explain why these streaks remain stubbornly intact,^100
even amid hurricane-force winds. They also have the odd habit^100
of absorbing ultraviolet radiation
venus.structure:
^800If we could slice Venus and Earth in half, pole to pole,^100
and place them side by side, they would look remarkably^100
similar. Each planet has an iron core enveloped by a hot-rock mantle;^100
the thinnest of skins forms a rocky, exterior crust. On both planets,^100
this thin skin changes form and sometimes erupts into volcanoes^100
in response to the ebb and flow of heat and^100
pressure deep beneath.

mars.first:
^800the fourth planet from the Sun, and the seventh largest.^100
It’s the only planet we know of inhabited entirely by robots.
mars.introduction:
^800Mars is one of the most explored bodies in our solar system,^100
and it's the only planet where we've sent rovers to^100
roam the alien landscape. NASA missions have found^100
lots of evidencethat Mars was much wetter and warmer,^100
with a thicker atmosphere,billions of years ago.
mars.namesake:
^800Mars was named by the ancient Romans for their god of war^100
because its reddish color was reminiscent of blood.^100
Other civilizations also named the planet for this attribute^100
– for example, the Egyptians called it Her Desher, meaning^100
the red one.Even today, it is frequently called the Red Planet^100
because iron minerals in the Martian dirt oxidize, or rust,^100
causing the surface to look red.
mars.potential:
^1000Scientists don't expect to find living things currently^100
thriving on Mars. Instead, they're looking for signs of life^100
that existed long ago, when Mars was warmer and covered^100
with water.
mars.structure:
^800Mars has a dense core at its center between^100
930 and 1,300 miles (1,500 to 2,100 kilometers) in radius.^100
It's made of iron, nickel, and sulfur. Surrounding the core^100
is a rockymantle between 770 and 1,170 miles^100
 (1,240 to 1,880 kilometers)thick, andabove that, a crust^100
made of iron, magnesium, aluminum, calcium,and^100
potassium.This crust is between 6 and 30 miles^100
(10 to 50 kilometers) deep.

Jupiter.first:
^800the fifth planet from the Sun, and the largest in the solar^100
system more than twice as massive as the other planets^100
combined.
Jupiter.introduction:
^800Jupiter's signature stripes and swirls are actually cold,^100
windy clouds of ammonia and water, floating in an^100
atmosphere of hydrogen and helium. The dark orange^100
stripes are called belts, while the bands are called^100
zones, and they flow east and west in opposite directions.^100
Jupiter’s iconic Great Red Spot is a giant storm bigger^100
than Earth that has for hundreds of years.
Jupiter.namesake:
^800Jupiter, being the biggest, gets its name from the king^100
of the ancient Roman gods
Jupiter.potential:
^1000Jupiter’s environment is probably not conducive to life^100
as we know it. The temperatures, pressures, and^100
materials that characterize this planet are most likely^100
 too extreme and volatilefor organisms to adapt to. While^100
 planet Jupiter is an unlikely place forliving things to^100
 take hold, the same is not true of some of its many moons.^100
Europa is one of the likeliest places to find life elsewhere^100
in our solar system.There is evidence of a vast ocean^100
just beneath its icy crust, wherelife could possibly^100
be supported.
Jupiter.structure:
^800The composition of Jupiter is similar to that of the Sun^100
– mostly hydrogen and helium. Deep in the atmosphere,^100
pressure and temperature increase, compressing^100
the hydrogen gas into a liquid.gives Jupiter the largest ocean^100
in the solar system –an ocean made ofinstead of water.^100
Scientists think that, at depths  perhaps halfway to planet's^100
center, the pressure becomes so great that electrons^100
are squeezed the hydrogen atoms, making the liquid electrically^100
conducting like metal.Jupiter's fast rotation is thought to drive^100
electrical currents in this region, the spinning of the liquid^100
metallic hydrogen acting like a dynamo, generatingplanet's^100
powerful magnetic field.Deeper down, Jupiter's central^100
core had longamystery. Scientiststheorized Jupiter was a mostly^100
homogeneous mix ofhydrogen and helium gases, surrounding^100
a small,solid core ofheavierelements – rock, and metal^100
formed from debris and small objects swirling aroundthat^100
area of the embryonicsolar system 4 billion years ago.

saturn.first:
^800the sixth planet from the Sun, and the second largest in the^100
solar system. It’s surrounded by beautiful rings.
saturn.introduction:
^800Like fellow gas giant Jupiter, Saturn is a massive ball^100
made mostly of hydrogen and helium. Saturn is not the only^100
planet to have rings, but none are as spectacular or as complex as^100
Saturn's. Saturn also has dozens of moons. From the jets of water that^100
spray from Saturn's moon Enceladus to the methane lakes on smoggy Titan,^100
the Saturn system is a rich source of scientific discovery and^100
still holds many mysteries.
saturn.namesake:
^800The farthest planet from Earth discovered by the unaided^100
human eye, Saturn has been known since ancient times. The planet is named^100
for the Roman god of agriculture and wealth, who was^100
also the father of Jupiter.
saturn.potential:
^1000Saturn's environment is^100
not conducive to life as we know it. The temperatures, pressures, and materials^100
that characterize this planet are most likely too extreme and volatile for^100
organisms to adapt to.
saturn.structure:
^800Like Jupiter, Saturn^100
is made mostly of hydrogen and helium. At Saturn's center is a dense core of^100
metals like iron and nickel surrounded by rocky material and other compounds^100
solidified by intense pressure and heat. It is enveloped by liquid metallic^100
hydrogen inside a layer of liquid hydrogen –similar to Jupiter's core but^100
considerably smaller. It's hard to imagine, but Saturn is the only planet in^100
our solar system with an average density that is less than water. The giant^100
gas planet could float in a bathtub if such a colossal thing existed.

Uranus.first:
^800the seventh planet from the Sun, and the third largest planet^100
in our solar system. It appears to spin sideways.
Uranus.introduction:
^800Uranus is a very cold and windy world. The ice giant is^100
surrounded by 13 faint rings and 28 small moons. Uranus rotates at a^100
nearly 90-degree angle from the plane of its orbit. This unique tilt makes^100
Uranus appear to spin sideways, orbiting the Sun like a rolling ball.^100
Uranus was the first planet found with the aid of a telescope. It was^100
discovered in 1781 by astronomer William Herschel, although he originally thought^100
it was either a comet or a star. It was two years later that the^100
object was universally accepted as a new planet, in part because of observations by^100
astronomer Johann Elert Bode.
Uranus.namesake:
^800William Herschel tried unsuccessfully to name his discovery^100
Georgium Sidus after King George III. Instead, the planet was^100
named for Uranus, the Greek god of the sky,^100
as suggested by Johann Bode.
Uranus.potential:
^1000Uranus' environment is not conducive to life as we know it.^100
The temperatures, pressures, and materials that characterize this planet^100
are most likely too extreme and volatile for organisms^100
to adapt to.
Uranus.structure:
^800Uranus is one of two ice giants in the outer solar system^100
(the other is Neptune). Most (80% or more) of the planet's^100
mass is made up of a hot dense fluid of icy materials – water, methane, and ammonia^100
– above a small rocky core. Near the core, it heats up to 9,000 degrees^100
Fahrenheit (4,982 degrees Celsius).Uranus is slightly larger in diameter^100
than its neighbor Neptune, yet smaller in mass. It is the second least^100
dense planet; Saturn is the least dense of all. Uranus gets its blue-green color^100
from methane gas in the atmosphere. Sunlight passes through the atmosphere^100
and is reflected back out by Uranus' cloud tops. Methane gas absorbs the red^100
portion of the light, resulting in a blue-green color.

neptune.first:
^800the eighth, and most distant planet from the Sun.^100
It’s the fourth-largest, and the first planet discovered with math.
neptune.introduction:
^800Dark, cold, and whipped by supersonic winds,^100
ice giant Neptune is more than 30 times as far from the Sun as Earth.^100
Neptune is the only planet in our solar system not visible to the naked eye.^100
In 2011 Neptune completed its first 165-year orbit since its discovery^100
in 1846.Neptune is so far from the Sun that high noon on the big blue planet would^100
seem like dim twilight to us. The warm light we see here on our home planet is^100
roughly 900 times as bright as sunlight on Neptune.
neptune.namesake:
^800The ice giant Neptune was the first planet located^100
through mathematical calculations. Using predictions made by Urbain^100
Le Verrier, Johann Galle discovered the planet in 1846. The planet is named^100
after the Roman god of the sea, as suggested by Le Verrier.
neptune.potential:
^1000Neptune's environment is not conducive^100
to life as we know it. The temperatures, pressures, and materials that^100
characterize this planet are most likely too extreme, and volatile for^100
organisms to adapt to.
neptune.structure:
^800Neptune is one of two ice giants in the outer solar system^100
(the other is Uranus). Most (80% or more) of the planet's mass^100
is made up of a hot dense fluid of icy materials – water, methane, and^100
ammonia – above a small, rocky core. Of the giant planets, Neptune is the densest.^100
Scientists think there might be an ocean of super hot water under Neptune's cold^100
clouds. It does not boil away because incredibly high^100
pressure keeps it locked inside.
